thread.title: Chief whip Julian Smith faces calls to resign over claims he told MPs to break 'pairing' agreement

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Chief whip Julian Smith faces calls to resign over claims he told MPs to break 'pairing' agreement
text:
News Chief whip Julian Smith faces calls to resign over claims he told MPs to break 'pairing' agreement It's been claimed Julian Smith told Tory colleagues to break agreements which help pregnant women continue as MPs Share Conservative Party Chief Whip Julian Smith (Image: Getty Images Europe) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Conservative chief whip Julian Smith faces calls to resign following reports that he urged three Tory MPs to abandon “pairing” arrangements before a crucial vote.
The pairing arrangement means MPs are not at a disadvantage if they are on maternity leave or have a long term illness.
If they can’t come in to the Commons to vote then an MP from a rival party - known as a “pair” - will also miss the vote, so that they cancel each other out.
But Mr Smith’s behaviour, if the reports are correct, makes it harder for pregnant women or mothers of young children to be MPs.
Labour Chair Ian Lavery , MP for Wansbeck, said on Twitter: “IMO the actions of Julian Smith and Brandon Lewis was worse than dishonest. It’s lower than the lowest of gutter politics.
“You’re both a total disgrace & puts to shame the integrity of the mother of all parliaments.”
Conservative Party chairman Brandon Lewis had been “paired” with Liberal Democrat deputy leader Jo Swinson, who is on maternity leave following the birth of her second son.
But the Tory MP then took part in two crunch Commons votes on Tuesday night and helped Prime Minister Theresa May narrowly avoid a damaging defeat on Brexit trade plans.
Mrs May has said Mr Lewis voted by mistake. She told MPs: “The breaking of the pair was done in error. It wasn’t good enough and will not be repeated.”
But the Times reported that Mr Smith, the chief whip, urged Mr Lewis and two other Tory MPs to vote despite being paired.
The Times said it has been told that the two other Conservative MPs ignored Mr Smith’s instruction. Read More Labour councillors 'uniting' over plans to stop them choosing council leaders
Ms Swinson said: ”This reflects pretty badly on those peddling the ‘honest mistake’ nonsense.
“To be fair, hats off to the two MPs who told their chief whip to take a running jump when he asked them to break a pairing just because the Government might lose.”
Ms Swinson said that a system of proxy voting should be introduced to the House of Commons.
This would allow MPs to cast a vote even if they cannot come to Westminster, ending the need for a pairing system.
Tom Watson (Lab West Bromwich East), Labour’s deputy leader, said: “Tory chief whip told three MPs to defy ‘pairing’ deals on crucial Brexit votes according to today’s Times.
“If true, this is despicable behaviour which makes politics even more inaccessible for women. If true, Julian Smith must resign, or be sacked.” Read More Leave campaign 'cheated' to win EU referendum - now North East MP wants Brexit to be scrapped
If Mr Smith does resign, he would be the third Cabinet Minister to quit Theresa May’s Government in recent weeks.
Former Brexit Secretary Davis Davis and former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson both resigned in protest at the Government’s proposed Brexit deal.
However, the Prime Minister’s spokesman insisted she still had full confidence in both Mr Smith and Mr Lewis.
Some Tories have also raised concerns about the claims.
They include MP Heidi Allen, who said: “I sincerely hope this isn’t true. No matter how tough the going gets, principle, integrity and standards matter. Without those, what’s left?” Like us on Facebook
